Title: Subsistence and Human Resilience to Sudden Climatic Events in Europe during MIS3

This project seeks to investigate the subsistence strategies of Neanderthals and Anatomically Modern Humans (AMH) in response to sudden climatic events during the Middle to Upper Palaeolithic transition in Southern European peninsulas. By analyzing 20 archaeological sites, we will employ a multi-disciplinary approach combining zooarchaeological, taphonomic, and stable isotope analyses to reconstruct local terrestrial climatic and environmental conditions. Our objectives are to assess the behavioural flexibility and resilience of both species, develop a procedure to estimate ecosystem carrying capacity, and understand the subsistence patterns that favored AMH. This research will provide new insights into the impact of climatic oscillations on Neanderthal extinction and AMH colonization, shedding light on the dynamics of human adaptation and resilience in the face of environmental change. The project's pan-European scope will contribute significantly to the field of prehistory, offering a comprehensive understanding of human-climate interactions during a critical period in human history. Ultimately, this research will inform our understanding of the complex relationships between climate, environment, and human societies, with implications for contemporary climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies.
